title: How to Easily Calculate Your Typing Speed and Accuracy

steps.title: Choose a passage of text to copy for your test.
steps.content: Choose a passage of text to copy for your test. You can use a famous quote, a passage from your favorite book, or any random words you want. Make sure the passage has at least 100 words. Keep the passage open on your computer.

steps.title: Type as many words as you can within 1 minute.
steps.content: Type as many words as you can within 1 minute. Open a text document on your computer, and set a timer for 1 minute on your phone. As soon as you hit start, start typing the words in the passage. Try to type as many words correctly as you can. It’s okay to leave spelling errors, but they will negatively impact your typing speed. Going back and fixing errors also takes more time and reduces your overall speed.

steps.title: Divide the number of characters typed by 5 to find your words per minute.
steps.content: Divide the number of characters typed by 5 to find your words per minute . Count the number of characters you typed, including spaces and punctuation marks. Divide the total amount by 5 and round down to find your average words per minute. [1] X Research source Example : If you typed 250 characters in total in 1 minute, then 250 ÷ 5 = 50 WPM . If you highlight the typed text and look for a “Word Count” option in the menu, it will also list the character count. You can always take longer typing tests to test your speed over different periods of time. Use the formula (number of characters ÷ 5) / number of minutes .

steps.title: Calculate accuracy by dividing correct characters by the total character count.
steps.content: Calculate accuracy by dividing correct characters by the total character count. Look back through the words you typed and compare it to the original text for any typos. Count each mistake you made and subtract it from the total number of characters. Use number of correct characters / number of total characters , multiply the result by 100, and round down to find your accuracy percentage. [2] X Research source Example : If you made 8 errors and typed 250 characters total, your accuracy is 242 ÷ 250 = 0.968 = 96% accuracy .

steps.title: Multiply your WPM by your accuracy for your net typing speed.
steps.content: Multiply your WPM by your accuracy for your net typing speed. Use the formula words per minute x accuracy percentage . Round the result down to find the adjusted typing speed. [3] X Research source Example : If you typed 50 words per minute with 96% accuracy, then 50 x 0.96 = 48 WPM . Alternatively, some people calculate their net typing speed as WPM - number of errors. Using this formula, if you type 50 WPM but make 8 errors, your net words per minute is 42.

steps.title: Use an online test to calculate typing speeds for you.
steps.content: Use an online test to calculate typing speeds for you. Multiple sites offer free typing tests to calculate your speed. Many tests will generate random lists of words or use famous quotes, plus they’ll highlight where you made errors. Some of the best free typing tests include: TypingTest Typing.com 10 Fast Fingers Key Hero TypeRacer Speed Typing Online

steps.title: 40 words per minute is the average typing speed.
steps.content: 40 words per minute is the average typing speed . This is the speed that’s common for most adults who regularly use a computer. If you type a little slower, work on improving your typing speed . [4] X Research source

steps.title: Aim for 60 WPM or higher for the most productivity.
steps.content: Aim for 60 WPM or higher for the most productivity. If you want to work in administrative positions or frequently use a computer, then work on building up to at least 60 WPM. As you keep practicing, you’ll start being able to type faster . [5] X Research source

steps.title: Sit up straight while you type.
steps.content: Sit up straight while you type. When you sit at your computer , using the correct posture can make typing easier and a lot faster. Whenever you’re sitting down to type, use the following posture: [6] X Research source Sit with your back straight against your chair’s backrest. Keep your feet flat on the floor. Position your keyboard so you can keep your elbows bent at 90 degrees and close to your sides.

steps.title: Position your fingers on your keyboard’s home row.
steps.content: Position your fingers on your keyboard’s home row. Place your left fingers on the A, S, D, and F keys, and put your right fingers on the J, K, L, and ; keys. Whenever you press a key, bring your fingers back to their starting positions on the home row. Keep both of your thumbs over the space bar so you can easily press it in between words. [7] X Research source Keeping your fingers on the home row helps you familiarize yourself with your keyboard and the letter locations.

steps.title: Practice typing without looking at your hands.
steps.content: Practice typing without looking at your hands. As you get more familiar with the layout of your keyboard, practice looking at your computer screen while you’re typing. That way, you can catch any typos you make faster so you don’t have to go back and edit them later on. [8] X Research source The F and J keys usually have a raised bump on them so you can easily feel where they are and reposition your fingers back on the home row.

steps.title: Think ahead to the next words while you’re typing.
steps.content: Think ahead to the next words while you’re typing. If you’re copying text, look ahead to the word after the current one you’re typing. If you’re writing something without a reference, plan out the next few words in your head. This can help you position your fingers for the next word so you don’t frequently start and stop typing. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Take typing tests frequently to check how you’ve improved.
steps.content: Take typing tests frequently to check how you’ve improved. As you keep practicing, make your own typing test or take one online to test your skills again. If you notice you’re having trouble with specific keystrokes, keep practicing them until they become natural.
